potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Without antihypertensive medication, three measurements on different days with SBP≥140mmHg and/or DBP≥90mmHg; or 24h ambulatory BP monitoring with daytime mean SBP≥135mmHg.
Secondary hypertension due to renal parenchymal or renovascular stenosis disease; often accompanied by proteinuria, eGFR decline, or imaging evidence.
Hypertension caused by endocrine disorders such as primary aldosteronism, pheochromocytoma, Cushing's syndrome.
Nighttime BP reduction <10%, nighttime SBP≥120mmHg, indicating abnormal circadian rhythm.
Polysomnography showing AHI≥5/hour with symptoms or AHI≥15/hour; nighttime non-dipper pattern (nighttime SBP decline <10%).
CKD with elevated or non-declining nighttime BP; commonly presents with proteinuria and eGFR decline.
MAP≥100mmHg, calculated as MAP = DBP + 1/3(SBP-DBP); persistent MAP≥105mmHg indicates elevation.
Elevated MAP with arterial pulse wave velocity (PWV) >10 m/s, indicating increased arterial stiffness.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Chronic Kidney Disease with Volume Overload
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: CKD with fluid retention, edema, and persistently elevated MAP.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Left Ventricular Hypertrophy / Hypertensive Heart Disease
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: LVMI >115 g/m² in males, >95 g/m² in females, measured by echocardiography or cardiac MRI; associated with long-term hypertension history.
CKD with elevated PTH or FGF23, phosphorus disorder, and increased LVMI.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: LVEF<40%, with heart failure symptoms (dyspnea, fatigue, edema, etc.) and abnormal biomarkers (e.g., elevated BNP).

LVEF<40-45%, left ventricular end-diastolic diameter increased, excluding coronary artery disease, valvular disease, and other causes; or imaging shows LV dilation with reduced LVEF, excluding ischemic etiology.
BNP>400 pg/mL or NT-proBNP>900 pg/mL, with acute dyspnea, pulmonary edema, and other symptoms.
BNP>100 pg/mL or elevated NT-proBNP combined with clinical symptoms/signs, potentially reduced LVEF; or BNP>100 pg/mL or elevated NT-proBNP with clinical symptoms/signs.
Elevated BNP (usually >150 pg/mL), with mean pulmonary arterial pressure≥25 mmHg (at rest) or >30 mmHg (during exercise).
CKD with elevated BNP and fluid retention signs.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: High-Risk Atherosclerotic Cardiovascular Disease (ASCVD) / Atherosclerotic Inflammation Activation
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: hsCRP>2.0 mg/L, indicating increased cardiovascular disease risk with other cardiovascular risk factors; or hsCRP≥2 mg/L suggesting elevated inflammatory risk associated with atherosclerosis.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Metabolic Syndrome with Chronic Inflammation / Type 2 Diabetes-Related Chronic Inflammation
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: hsCRP>3.0 mg/L, with central obesity (WC≥90cm male, ≥80cm female), hypertension, dyslipidemia, hyperglycemia, etc.; or T2DM with elevated inflammatory markers (hsCRP>2 mg/L).
hsCRP persistently elevated >5.0 mg/L, with history of rheumatic diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus.

FMD<6%, indicating impaired vascular endothelium-dependent dilation function, an early marker of atherosclerosis; or FMD reduction (e.g., <6%) suggesting impaired endothelium-dependent dilation function.
FMD<5%, with carotid intima-media thickness (IMT)>0.9mm or atherosclerotic plaque formation.
FMD commonly reduced in T2DM patients.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Microvascular Endothelial Dysfunction / Smoking-Related Endothelial Dysfunction
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: RHI<1.67, indicating impaired peripheral microvascular endothelial function, associated with increased cardiovascular event risk; or RHI reduction (e.g., <1.67) with smoking history.
RHI<2.0, with typical angina symptoms but no significant stenosis on coronary angiography (<50%), suggesting coronary microcirculation disorder.
RHI reduced in OSA patients, often coexisting with nighttime hypertension.
Carotid IMT annual growth rate >0.02 mm/y or progressive IMT thickening (IMT_slope>0 mm/y), suggesting atherosclerosis progression and increased cardiovascular event risk.
IMT annual growth rate >0.015 mm/y, with LDL-C>130 mg/dL or non-HDL-C>160 mg/dL.
IMT annual growth rate >0.018 mm/y, with metabolic syndrome (central obesity, elevated BP, abnormal glucose, dyslipidemia).
Central SBP ≥130 mmHg, or central-peripheral SBP difference >10 mmHg, indicating increased large artery stiffness.
Central SBP ≥140 mmHg with DBP <90 mmHg, commonly seen in elderly patients.

Three measurements on different days without antihypertensive medication, office SBP ≥140 mmHg and/or DBP ≥90 mmHg; or ambulatory monitoring daytime ≥135/85 mmHg, with elevated cSBP consistent with peripheral BP.
Elevated pulse wave velocity (PWV) or increased β-stiffness index, with increased cSBP and wave reflection.
Augmentation pressure ≥15 mmHg, indicating increased large artery stiffness and enhanced wave reflection.
Decreased peripheral or central arterial compliance, elevated wave reflection coefficient and AIx (augmentation index), with increased AP.
Age ≥65 years, widened pulse pressure, decreased arterial compliance, predominantly systolic elevation; AP commonly elevated.
β-stiffness index ≥12, indicating significantly increased carotid artery wall stiffness.
β-stiffness index ≥10, with dyslipidemia or other cardiovascular risk factors.
Ultrasound showing carotid IMT thickening or plaque formation, with elevated β-stiffness index.
Elevated serum phosphate, PTH or FGF23, with vascular calcification/arterial stiffness.
CAC score ≥100 Agatston units indicates moderate coronary calcification; ≥400 indicates severe calcification.

parameters.note: Statins can slow calcification progression but cannot reverse it

targetValueRange.note: Goal is to slow progression rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Elevated CAC score with eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73m², elevated serum phosphate or PTH.
Quantitative coronary CT CAC >0 or follow-up progression rate higher than same-age population, indicating high atherosclerotic burden.
Elevated serum phosphate, PTH or FGF23, with accelerated vascular calcification.
Chest pain lasting >20 minutes, ECG ST-segment elevation ≥0.1mV (≥2 adjacent leads), elevated cardiac markers.

parameters.note: Reduces recurrent MI risk by approximately 25%
Further reduces cardiovascular event risk by 16% compared to clopidogrel
Reduces mortality and reinfarction risk

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Elevated cardiac markers, ECG ST-segment depression or T-wave inversion, but no ST-segment elevation.

parameters.note: Acute phase anticoagulation therapy

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Increased coronary artery stenosis/plaque rupture risk (imaging/clinical assessment), increased annual event risk.
Elevated lipoprotein(a) (Lpa), with atherosclerotic burden or increased event risk.
Ankle-brachial index (ABI) <0.9, with intermittent claudication or rest pain.

parameters.note: Improve walking distance
Reduce cardiovascular event risk

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Diabetic patients, ABI <0.9 or >1.3, with lower extremity ulcer or gangrene risk.

parameters.note: Improve lower limb perfusion

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: ABI <0.90 or imaging-confirmed lower limb arterial stenosis/occlusion.
Confirmed diabetes history with PAD clinical or imaging evidence.
RMSSD <20ms, indicating decreased parasympathetic nerve activity and impaired autonomic function.
Reduced HRV, RMSSD <15ms, with symptoms of cardiac dysfunction.
Continuous ECG analysis shows RMSSD below age- and gender-reference range, with nighttime HRV reduction.
Long-term heavy alcohol consumption, reduced HRV, with increased blood pressure fluctuation.
24-hour blood pressure standard deviation >15 mmHg, indicating excessive blood pressure fluctuation.
Rapid morning BP increase, morning surge >35 mmHg, increased BP variability.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Essential hypertension with increased blood pressure variability
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: 24-hour ambulatory BP SD or ARV above population reference upper limit, with elevated mean BP.
Long-term high alcohol intake, elevated mean BP and BPV.
SBP 140-159 mmHg or DBP 90-99 mmHg, no evidence of secondary hypertension.

parameters.note: Approximately 65% of patients achieve BP target
Approximately 75% of patients achieve BP target

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: SBP 160-179 mmHg or DBP 100-109 mmHg.

parameters.note: Approximately 70% of patients achieve BP target
Approximately 80% of patients achieve BP target

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Multiple BP measurements reaching diagnostic threshold without medication (office ≥140/90 mmHg or corresponding ambulatory BP threshold).

parameters.currentProb: Current probability of meeting diagnostic criteria (0-1)
Current probability of meeting diagnostic criteria (0-1)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Elevated BP caused by renal parenchymal disease or renovascular lesions, with proteinuria/altered renal function.

parameters.currentProb: Current probability of meeting diagnostic criteria (0-1)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Hypertensive patients with LVMI >115 g/m² (male) or >95 g/m² (female).

parameters.note: Long-term treatment can reverse left ventricular hypertrophy
Cardiovascular protective effect

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Hypertension with eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73m² or elevated urinary albumin/creatinine ratio.

calculation.formula: Reduce proteinuria and slow renal function decline

parameters.note: Dual excretion pathway, safer in renal insufficiency

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: LVEF <40%, with heart failure symptoms.

parameters.note: Reduce mortality and rehospitalization rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Meets hypertension diagnosis and has cardiac, renal, cerebral or other target organ risk, or requires RAAS blockade therapy.
Albuminuria A2/A3 or proteinuria ≥0.3 g/d, requires RAAS blockade for renal protection.
Without antihypertensive medication, three measurements on different days with SBP≥140mmHg and/or DBP≥90mmHg

calculation.method: Logistic probability model (medication assignment probability increases)

parameters.Δ: +1.2 (represents increase in log odds of initiating ARB prescription)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Diabetic patients with urinary albumin/creatinine ratio≥30mg/g, or eGFR<60 mL/min/1.73m²

calculation.method: Logistic probability model (more likely to initiate when proteinuria present)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Clinical symptoms (dyspnea, edema) with LVEF≤40% or BNP≥100 pg/mL
SBP 140-179mmHg and/or DBP 90-109mmHg, without other complications

calculation.method: Logistic probability model (medication assignment probability increases)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Age≥65 years, SBP≥140mmHg, DBP<90mmHg
History of at least two calcium stone episodes with elevated urinary calcium
Typical angina symptoms, coronary angiography showing ≥50% stenosis or positive stress test

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Chronic Heart Failure (Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: NYHA II-IV, LVEF≤40%
Atrial fibrillation or supraventricular tachycardia, resting heart rate >100 bpm
Confirmed acute myocardial infarction during discharge and outpatient follow-up

calculation.method: Logistic probability model (medication assignment probability increases)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: ECG confirmed atrial fibrillation, requiring ventricular rate control
Continuous smoking ≥6 months, daily smoking ≥10 cigarettes, with withdrawal symptoms
Current smoking with cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or diabetes)
Meets DSM/ICD addiction/dependence diagnostic criteria, persistent smoking behavior
Pulmonary function test FEV1/FVC<0.70 with smoking history
Daily alcohol intake exceeding 40g pure alcohol for males, 20g for females, lasting ≥12 months, with withdrawal symptoms

calculation.method: Logistic probability model (high drinking probability decrease)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: History of long-term heavy drinking, LVEF<50%, elevated BNP, excluding other causes of cardiomyopathy

calculation.formula: Complete abstinence required to improve cardiac function

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: In the past 12 months, meets multiple criteria for impaired/loss-of-control alcohol use

calculation.method: Logistic probability model (high drinking probability decrease)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Mild cognitive decline, hippocampal volume reduction >1.5 SD, memory score decline

calculation.formula: Approximately 30% reduction in annual atrophy rate
Approximately 25% reduction in annual atrophy rate

calculation.method: Linear slope reduction (hippocampal volume annual decline reduction)

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Temporal Lobe Epilepsy with Hippocampal Sclerosis
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Recurrent focal seizures, imaging shows hippocampal volume reduction and T2 signal increase
History of long-term depression or anxiety, hippocampal volume reduction, mild cognitive decline
Meets diagnostic criteria for depressive episode, excluding organic lesions
Progressive cognitive decline, global cortical thickness reduction >2 SD, especially in temporoparietal regions

calculation.formula: Approximately 35% reduction in annual atrophy rate
Approximately 40% reduction in annual atrophy rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Behavioral or language abnormalities predominant, frontal and anterior temporal cortical thinning

calculation.formula: Approximately 20% reduction in annual atrophy rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: White matter lesions with cortical thinning, cognitive decline, vascular risk factors

calculation.method: Improving cerebral blood flow to protect cortex
calculation.formula: Approximately 25% reduction in annual atrophy rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Imaging shows WMH/lacunes/microbleeds with long-term hypertension history

calculation.method: Linear slope reduction (cortical thickness thinning rate decrease)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Elevated non-HDL cholesterol/LDL-C

calculation.method: Inflammation burden decrease → cortical thinning slope slightly reduced (empirical model)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: MRI shows diffuse or patchy white matter hyperintensities, often with cognitive decline

calculation.formula: Approximately 30% reduction in annual progression rate
Approximately 25% reduction in annual progression rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: History of long-term hypertension, white matter hyperintensity volume increase, poor blood pressure control

calculation.method: Blood pressure control reduces white matter damage
calculation.formula: Approximately 35% reduction in annual progression rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Relapsing-remitting clinical symptoms, MRI shows multiple demyelinating lesions

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Cerebral Small Vessel Disease/Hypertension-Related Brain Lesions
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: MRI shows increased WMH with long-term elevated blood pressure

calculation.method: Linear growth rate decrease (WMH volume annual increase slowing)

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Type 2 Diabetes with Elevated Blood Pressure
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Confirmed T2DM with clinic or ambulatory blood pressure elevation
MRI shows deep infarcts <15mm in diameter, often with hypertension or diabetes

calculation.formula: Approximately 25% reduction in annual new infarct risk

calculation.method: Event generation rate decrease (new lacunes reduction)

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Cerebral Small Vessel Disease with Lacunes
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Multiple lacunar infarcts, with white matter hyperintensities and vascular risk factors

calculation.formula: Approximately 20% reduction in stroke recurrence risk

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Poor blood pressure control, imaging reveals multiple lacunes but asymptomatic

calculation.method: Intensive blood pressure lowering reduces new infarcts
calculation.formula: Approximately 40% reduction in new lacune risk

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Lacunar Cerebral Infarction History (Small Vessel Disease)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: MRI shows basal ganglia/thalamus/brainstem ≤15mm lacunar lesions

calculation.method: Event generation rate decrease (new lacunes reduction)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Multiple microbleeds (≥5) in lobar regions, typically elderly patients, possibly with cognitive decline

recommendedDrugs.drugName: Strict Blood Pressure Control (without antiplatelet drugs)

calculation.formula: Approximately 30% reduction in new microbleed rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Multiple microbleeds in deep brain tissue (basal ganglia, thalamus), history of long-term hypertension

calculation.method: Blood pressure control reduces new microbleeds
calculation.formula: Approximately 35% reduction in new microbleed rate

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Patients on anticoagulant therapy (e.g., warfarin), imaging shows increased microbleeds

calculation.formula: Approximately 60% reduction in bleeding risk compared to warfarin
Approximately 58% reduction in bleeding risk compared to warfarin

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Elderly patients, lobar posterior parietal/occipital subcortical microbleeds, with amyloid-related presentations

recommendedDrugs.drugClass: ARB (Blood pressure control, reducing new microbleed risk)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Long-term hypertension, deep (basal ganglia/brainstem) microbleeds predominant

recommendedDrugs.drugClass: Dihydropyridine Calcium Channel Blocker (blood pressure lowering)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Imaging findings of lacunar infarcts, white matter hyperintensities and other cerebral small vessel disease markers, without obvious clinical symptoms.

calculation.formula: Reduce new SCI risk by approximately 30%
Reduce new SCI risk by approximately 35%

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Presence of cardiac diseases such as atrial fibrillation or valvular heart disease, with imaging showing multiple cerebral infarctions.

calculation.formula: Reduce new SCI risk by approximately 60%

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: ECG/Holter monitoring confirmed atrial fibrillation, MRI showing scattered asymptomatic cortical/subcortical punctate infarctions.

parameters.t: Weeks after medication (for time-based updates, RRR assessed at 52 weeks)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Cerebral blood flow below normal range (normal: 50-60 mL/100g/min), possibly accompanied by cognitive decline or dizziness.
Long-term cerebral hypoperfusion with cognitive decline, gait instability and other clinical manifestations.
Carotid ultrasound/CTA/MRA showing ≥50% stenosis (NEURO:Carotid_sten/NEURO:ICAS), perfusion imaging showing regional CBF reduction.
Decreased hemoglobin (RENAL:Hb) with fatigue and pale skin/mucosa; generalized CBF reduction.

recommendedDrugs.drugName: Oral iron supplement (ferrous sulfate or ferrous fumarate)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Reduced cerebrovascular reactivity to CO2 stimulation, indicating cerebrovascular regulatory dysfunction.
Carotid or intracranial artery stenosis (NEURO:Carotid_sten/NEURO:ICAS) or smoking history (CARDIO:Smoking_status), reduced CVR on CO2 challenge or acetazolamide challenge test.
Executive function test scores below normal range, but daily living abilities basically preserved, not meeting diagnostic criteria for dementia.
Presence of cerebrovascular lesions with executive dysfunction as the main manifestation.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Vascular mild cognitive impairment (small vessel disease phenotype)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Executive dysfunction predominant, imaging showing increased NEURO:WMH_vol/presence of NEURO:Lacunes, daily living abilities basically preserved.
Elevated PHQ-9 (NEURO:PHQ9), impaired executive function and attention control, excluding dementia.

calculation.method: PHQ improvement drives linear increase in executive score

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Cerebral small vessel disease-related cognitive impairment
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Presence of white matter lesions with slowed information processing speed as prominent manifestation.
Inattention, slowed information processing speed, affecting work and learning efficiency.
Elevated NEURO:Sleepiness score, slowed attention/reaction speed.
Imaging showing increased NEURO:WMH_vol or presence of NEURO:Microbleeds, with decreased information processing speed.
Significant decline in episodic memory with abnormal biomarkers (e.g., decreased CSF Aβ42, elevated tau protein).
Imaging showing reduced hippocampal volume, impaired memory function.
Elevated NEURO:PHQ9 score, subjective memory complaints but objective scale scores heavily influenced by suggestion.

calculation.method: Symptom relief drives memory score improvement

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: PHQ-9 score ≥10, meeting DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for major depressive disorder, lasting at least 2 weeks.
Depression symptoms appearing after stroke with elevated PHQ-9 score.
GAD-7 score ≥10, meeting DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for generalized anxiety disorder, symptoms persisting for at least 6 months.
Recurrent panic attacks with intense anxiety and somatic symptoms.
Recurrent sudden intense anxiety or panic attacks with autonomic symptoms.

dosage.frequency: 1-2 times daily as needed (not recommended for long-term use)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Annual decline in cognitive function exceeding normal aging expectations.

calculation.formula: Reduce cognitive decline event incidence by approximately 30%
Reduce cognitive decline event incidence by approximately 20%

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Presence of cerebrovascular lesions with stepwise cognitive decline.

calculation.formula: Reduce vascular cognitive decline event incidence by approximately 35%
Reduce vascular cognitive decline event incidence by approximately 25%

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Alzheimer's disease-related mild cognitive impairment (MCI due to AD)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Objective cognitive impairment but daily function basically preserved; imaging/biomarkers suggest Alzheimer's disease pathology possibility.
Executive function/processing speed decline predominant, imaging showing increased NEURO:WMH_vol and NEURO:Lacunes.
Progressive memory and cognitive decline meeting Alzheimer's disease clinical diagnostic criteria, may be accompanied by abnormal biomarkers.

calculation.formula: Delay moderate to severe dementia progression by 4-8 months
Combination therapy delays dementia progression by 8-14 months

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Cognitive dysfunction after cerebrovascular lesion, meeting diagnostic criteria for vascular dementia.

calculation.formula: Delay vascular dementia progression by 5-10 months
Reduce vascular dementia incidence risk by approximately 30%

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Coexistence of Alzheimer's disease pathology and cerebrovascular lesions.

calculation.formula: Delay mixed dementia progression by 6-10 months

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Mild cognitive impairment stage, biomarkers or imaging suggest Alzheimer's disease pathology.
High atherosclerosis risk, large NEURO:WMH_vol or increased NEURO:Lacunes, impaired executive function/processing speed.

calculation.method: Relative risk reduction (indirect through vascular mechanism)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Acute neurological deficit with imaging-confirmed cerebral infarction, NIHSS score ≥5 indicates moderate to severe stroke.
CT or MRI confirmed intracranial bleeding with neurological deficits.
Residual neurological disability after stroke, mRS score 2-5.
DSA, CTA or MRA showing intracranial artery stenosis ≥50%.
Carotid ultrasound, CTA or MRA showing carotid stenosis ≥50%.
Polysomnography with AHI ≥15 events/hour, accompanied by excessive daytime sleepiness (ESS >10).
Recurrent irresistible sleep episodes, with or without cataplexy.
Annual eGFR decline >5 mL/min/1.73m², sustained for more than 3 months.
History of diabetes, urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio (ACR) >30mg/g, other kidney diseases excluded.

calculation.formula: Increased probability of improvement from A3 to A2 or A1
Probability of categorical improvement increases logarithmically with treatment time

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: History of diabetes, eGFR >120 mL/min/1.73m², defined as glomerular hyperfiltration.
Serum cystatin C >1.20 mg/L, indicating decreased renal function.
Male serum uric acid >7.0 mg/dL, female >6.0 mg/dL.
Hyperuricemia with arthritis attacks, or urate crystals found in joint fluid.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Chronic Kidney Disease-Mineral and Bone Disorder (CKD-MBD)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: eGFR <60 mL/min/1.73m² with serum phosphate >4.5 mg/dL, accompanied by elevated PTH and calcium-phosphate metabolism disorder.
Post-chemotherapy serum phosphate >6.5 mg/dL, accompanied by elevated uric acid, potassium and decreased calcium.
Serum phosphate ≥4.5 mg/dL within 48-72 hours after chemotherapy for malignant tumors, combined with hyperuricemia/hyperkalemia or elevated creatinine.
Serum calcium >10.5 mg/dL with inappropriately elevated PTH.
Serum calcium <8.5 mg/dL, possibly accompanied by tetany, paresthesia or arrhythmia.
CKD stages 3-5 with elevated PTH and serum calcium <8.5 mg/dL.
CKD patients with PTH >70 pg/mL (stage G3) or >110 pg/mL (stages G4-5), accompanied by hyperphosphatemia or hypocalcemia.

dosage.frequency: Every other day or three times weekly

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: PTH >65 pg/mL, accompanied by 25-hydroxyvitamin D <20 ng/mL.
Elevated serum calcium with elevated PTH, excluding secondary causes.
CKD patients with FGF23 >100 pg/mL, accompanied by declining renal function and mineral metabolism disorder.
FGF23 >150 pg/mL, accompanied by hypophosphatemia and abnormal vitamin D metabolism.
Hypophosphatemia, elevated FGF23, evidence of focal mesenchymal tumor.
Serum albumin <3.0 g/dL, accompanied by massive proteinuria (>3.5g/24h), edema and hyperlipidemia.
Serum albumin <3.5 g/dL, accompanied by decreased BMI, muscle wasting and weight loss.
Serum albumin <3.5 g/dL, combined with medical history suggesting malnutrition or chronic inflammation.
CKD patients with hemoglobin <11 g/dL (males <13 g/dL, females <12 g/dL), accompanied by relative erythropoietin deficiency.

dosage.frequency: Once weekly or once every two weeks

sideEffects.notes: High hemoglobin target (>13g/dL) may increase cardiovascular event risk

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Hemoglobin <12 g/dL (females) or <13 g/dL (males), accompanied by ferritin <30 ng/mL or transferrin saturation <20%.
Hb <12 g/dL (females) or <13 g/dL (males), excluding iron deficiency, bleeding, etc.
Decreased Hb with low ferritin and decreased transferrin saturation.
Diabetic patients with urine protein >0.5 g/day, accompanied by declining eGFR and retinopathy.
Urine protein >3.5 g/day, possibly accompanied by hematuria, edema and hypoalbuminemia.
Diabetes history with persistent proteinuria (≥0.3 g/d).
Renal biopsy confirms IgA deposition with persistent proteinuria.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Type 2 Diabetes with Chronic Kidney Disease
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Type 2 diabetes patients with eGFR 20-90 mL/min/1.73m², with or without albuminuria.
Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) or heart failure with mildly reduced ejection fraction (HFmrEF).
Persistent proteinuria ≥0.3 g/d, eGFR may be normal or decreased.
CKD patients with urine albumin/creatinine ratio >30 mg/g or proteinuria >0.15 g/day.
Diabetic patients with microalbuminuria (30-300 mg/day) or overt proteinuria (>300 mg/day).
Persistent proteinuria ≥0.3 g/d, with or without hypertension.
CKD patients with urine albumin/creatinine ratio >30 mg/g or proteinuria >0.15 g/day, especially those intolerant to ACEI.
Type 2 diabetes patients with microalbuminuria or overt proteinuria, intolerant to ACEI or with significant cough side effects.
Renal biopsy confirms IgA nephropathy with proteinuria ≥0.3 g/d.
Diabetes with proteinuria ≥0.3 g/d.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Acute Heart Failure with Volume Overload
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Presence of dyspnea, pulmonary rales, lower extremity edema, imaging showing pulmonary congestion, BNP>400pg/mL

sideEffects.description: Excessive diuresis may lead to hypochloremic alkalosis

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: eGFR<60 mL/min/1.73m² for >3 months, with lower extremity edema or generalized edema

sideEffects.expectedTrend: Decreased blood volume may cause relative increase in serum albumin

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Serum bicarbonate <22 mmol/L, eGFR<60 mL/min/1.73m², normal anion gap
Normal anion gap metabolic acidosis, abnormal urine pH (RTA Type I >5.5, RTA Type II variable)

sideEffects.description: Especially suitable for distal RTA patients prone to kidney stones

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: History of 2 or more kidney stones, stone analysis showing calcium oxalate, 24-hour urine oxalate >40mg

targetValueRange.description: Normalized urine calcium, reduced stone risk

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Stone analysis showing uric acid stones, serum uric acid >7mg/dL, urine pH <5.5

sideEffects.description: Lowering uric acid may slow CKD progression

targetValueRange.description: Urine pH 6.5-7.0, dissolve uric acid stones

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Familial cystinuria, urine cystine >250mg/day, characteristic hexagonal crystals
Dietary sodium intake >6g/day, blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg, salt-sensitive hypertension

calculation.method: Increased sodium excretion, blood pressure reduction

targetValueRange.description: Better effect combined with low sodium diet (<5g/day)

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Chronic Kidney Disease with High Sodium Intake
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: eGFR<60 mL/min/1.73m², dietary sodium >5g/day, proteinuria or edema

calculation.method: Reduce proteinuria, slow kidney function decline

targetValueRange.description: Best effect combined with low sodium diet

sideEffects.expectedTrend: Initial possible mild decline then improvement

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Serum potassium <3.5 mmol/L, use of loop or thiazide diuretics, possible muscle weakness, arrhythmia

sideEffects.expectedTrend: Need to avoid excessive potassium supplementation

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Serum potassium >5.5 mmol/L, eGFR<30 mL/min/1.73m², use of ACEI/ARB
Male waist circumference ≥90cm, female ≥85cm (Asian criteria), with 2 or more of: high TG, low HDL-C, hypertension, hyperglycemia

targetValueRange.description: Waist circumference reduced by 3-8cm, weight loss 5-10%
Waist circumference reduced by 5-12cm, weight loss 10-15%
Waist circumference reduced by 2-5cm, weight loss 3-5%

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Reproductive-age females, waist circumference ≥85cm, irregular menstruation, hyperandrogenism, ultrasound showing polycystic ovaries

targetValueRange.description: Waist circumference reduced by 2-4cm, improved menstrual cycle

sideEffects.description: Diarrhea and nausea common, slow titration can reduce symptoms

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Male WHR>0.90, female WHR>0.85, indicating visceral fat accumulation

targetValueRange.description: WHR decreased, visceral fat preferentially reduced

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Metabolic Syndrome with High Waist-Hip Ratio
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Abnormally elevated WHR, combined with ≥3 metabolic abnormalities: hypertension, hyperglycemia, high TG, low HDL-C
DXA-measured VAT>100 cm² (female) or >130 cm² (male), with metabolic disorders

targetValueRange.description: Significantly reduced VAT, improved metabolic parameters
Dramatically reduced VAT, comprehensive metabolic improvement

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Significantly increased VAT, HbA1c≥6.5% or FPG≥7.0 mmol/L, insulin resistance

calculation.method: Reduce visceral fat and improve glucose

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Significantly increased SAT, BMI≥30 kg/m², excessive subcutaneous fat accumulation
Abnormally reduced or abnormally distributed SAT, possible insulin resistance and metabolic syndrome

calculation.formula: Improve insulin resistance and lipid abnormalities
calculation.expectedMeanChange: SAT itself does not increase, but metabolism improves

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Non-HDL cholesterol ≥4.9 mmol/L (190 mg/dL), both LDL-C and TG elevated

sideEffects.description: Long-term use can slow coronary calcification

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Non-HDL-C>5.7 mmol/L (220 mg/dL), positive family history, possible xanthomas
Elevated non-HDL-C, with high TG, low HDL-C, abdominal obesity, insulin resistance

targetValueRange.description: Mainly reduces TG, moderate improvement in nonHDL-C

sideEffects.description: Watch for myopathy risk when combined with statin

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: ApoA1 < 1.0 g/L, often accompanied by decreased HDL-C, increasing cardiovascular disease risk.

sideEffects.note: Cystatin C increase reflects mild decline in kidney function

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Presence of at least 3 of: abdominal obesity, hypertension, hyperglycemia, hypertriglyceridemia, and low HDL-C/ApoA1.
Two fasting tests on different days: HDL-C decreased (male <1.0 mmol/L; female <1.3 mmol/L) and/or ApoA1 <1.2 g/L; excluding secondary factors (inflammation, liver disease, malnutrition, etc.).

Metabolic syndrome (≥3 of: increased waist circumference, elevated triglycerides, decreased HDL-C, elevated blood pressure, elevated fasting glucose) or confirmed type 2 diabetes, accompanied by low ApoA1.
Lipoprotein(a) > 30 mg/dL, hereditary risk factor, associated with increased risk of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease.
LDL-C significantly elevated (>4.9 mmol/L) combined with elevated Lp(a), with family history of premature cardiovascular disease.
Two tests on different days showing Lp(a) ≥50 mg/dL, with no acute phase response.
Confirmed atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease with Lp(a) ≥30 mg/dL.
Triglycerides ≥ 2.3 mmol/L, remnant cholesterol elevated (>0.9 mmol/L), increasing atherosclerosis risk.

dosage.frequency: Once daily or divided into two doses

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Total cholesterol ≥ 6.2 mmol/L and triglycerides ≥ 2.3 mmol/L, remnant cholesterol significantly elevated.
Fasting triglycerides ≥2.3 mmol/L or VLDL elevation, Remnant_C >0.8 mmol/L.
Meets metabolic syndrome diagnostic criteria with elevated remnant cholesterol.
Small dense LDL proportion > 50%, commonly seen in patients with metabolic syndrome and diabetes, with stronger atherogenic properties.
HbA1c ≥ 6.5%, elevated small dense LDL proportion, often accompanied by hypertriglyceridemia.
Elevated fasting glucose or impaired glucose tolerance, accompanied by elevated sdLDL proportion (>40%).
Positive family history, elevated non-HDL-C and triglycerides, increased sdLDL proportion.
TyG index ≥ 8.5, reflecting insulin resistance state, commonly seen in metabolic syndrome and prediabetes.
HbA1c ≥ 6.5% or fasting glucose ≥ 7.0 mmol/L, TyG index significantly elevated.
TyG elevation (e.g., ≥8.5–8.8), with impaired fasting glucose or elevated HOMA-IR.
Meets diabetes diagnostic criteria (fasting glucose ≥7.0 mmol/L or OGTT 2h ≥11.1 mmol/L, etc.), with elevated TyG.
Postprandial GLP-1 level < 5 pmol/L, impaired insulin secretion, commonly seen in early type 2 diabetes.

calculation.formula: Pharmacological concentration (endogenous GLP-1 not directly measured)

parameters.note: Exogenous GLP-1 receptor agonist does not change endogenous GLP-1 measurements

calculation.formula: Pharmacological concentration (endogenous GLP-1 not directly measured)

parameters.note: Long-acting GLP-1 receptor agonist

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: BMI ≥ 28 kg/m2 (Chinese standard), accompanied by metabolic abnormalities, weakened GLP-1 secretion response.
Oral glucose or postprandial GLP-1 response below age/sex reference range.
Postprandial GLP-1 peak or increment below normal population reference with obesity.
Fasting serum Ghrelin significantly elevated (>200 pmol/L), accompanied by uncontrollable appetite hyperactivity and obesity.
BMI < 17.5, Ghrelin level significantly elevated (compensatory), but appetite suppressed.

parameters.note: As weight recovers, Ghrelin level gradually decreases

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Significant weight loss or low body weight, elevated ghrelin.
Elevated BMI, fasting/postprandial ghrelin below reference.
Meets diabetes diagnostic criteria with indications for weight management or cardiovascular-renal benefits.
Adult BMI ≥30, or BMI ≥27 with weight-related comorbidities.
Fasting glucose 5.6–6.9 mmol/L or OGTT 2h 7.8–11.0 mmol/L, high-risk population considering pharmacological intervention.
First-line medication indication clearly established (excluding contraindications).
Poor glycemic control or cardiovascular-renal risk, considering addition of SGLT2 inhibitor.
Elevated urinary protein (g/d) or UACR, eGFR allows medication use.
Non-HDL-C or LDL-C above target.
Confirmed ASCVD requiring intensive lipid-lowering.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Familial Hypercholesterolemia (or Very High Risk Not at Goal)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Maximum tolerated statin ± ezetimibe still not at goal.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: ASCVD Very High Risk Not at Goal
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Intensive statin therapy still not at goal.
Sodium intake > 6 g/d, blood pressure sensitive to sodium intake changes (positive sodium loading test), commonly seen in hypertensive patients.

calculation.method: Promotes sodium excretion (dietary sodium intake monitoring unchanged)
calculation.formula: Sodium intake itself unchanged, but urinary sodium excretion increases

parameters.note: This indicator reflects dietary intake, medication does not change intake amount

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73m2, high sodium intake aggravates kidney burden and proteinuria.
Multiple measurements in unmedicated state showing blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg or abnormal ambulatory blood pressure; salt-sensitive patients often have high sodium intake.

recommendedDrugs.drugName: Potassium chloride salt substitute (reduced sodium, increased potassium)

dosage.maintenanceDose: Adjusted according to taste and nutritional guidance

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Confirmed heart failure with tendency for fluid retention, recommended dietary sodium restriction.

recommendedDrugs.drugName: Potassium chloride salt substitute (auxiliary sodium restriction)

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Daily steps < 5000, accompanied by metabolic syndrome, obesity, or cardiovascular disease risk factors.

calculation.method: Behavioral indicator (medication does not directly change)

parameters.note: Medication combined with exercise prescription can enhance activity level

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: HbA1c ≥ 6.5%, daily steps significantly below recommended level.

calculation.formula: Glycemic control improvement may enhance activity capacity

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Joint X-ray/clinical diagnosis confirmed, limited activity, reduced steps.
PHQ-9 score indicating moderate or higher depression, reduced activity.
Moderate-to-vigorous physical activity < 30 min/d, accompanied by hypertension, dyslipidemia, or obesity.

calculation.formula: Medication treatment combined with exercise intervention
Exercise capacity improves after blood pressure control

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: BMI ≥ 28 kg/m2, MVPA significantly insufficient (< 15 min/d).

calculation.method: Activity capacity improves after weight loss

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Physical activity monitoring indicates MVPA insufficient (<30 min/d), combined with overweight/obesity.
PHQ-9 indicates depression, reduced activity.
VO2max < 25 mL/kg/min (male) or < 20 mL/kg/min (female), significantly increased risk of cardiovascular disease and all-cause mortality.

calculation.method: Exercise capacity improves after cardiac function improvement

parameters.note: Applicable to heart failure patients

potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: LVEF < 40%, VO2max significantly decreased (< 15 mL/kg/min), reduced exercise tolerance.

potentialDiseases.diseaseName: Heart Failure (Preserved or Reduced Ejection Fraction)
potentialDiseases.diagnosticCriteria: Confirmed heart failure diagnosis, decreased exercise endurance (low VO2max).
Excessive weight/fat mass and VO2max below same-age reference.
